definition.name: NXregion

symbols.doc: These symbols will denote how the shape of the parent group's data field could be split into a left set of ``O`` outer dimensions and a right set of ``R`` region dimensions where the data field has rank ``O+D``. Note ``O >= 0``.

definition.doc:
Geometry and logical description of a region of detector data. When used, it could be a child group to NXdetector.
This can be used to describe a subset of data used to create downsampled data or to derive some data from that subset.
Note, the fields for the rectangular region specifiers follow HDF5’s dataspace hyperslab parameters (see https://portal.hdfgroup.org/display/HDF5/H5S_SELECT_HYPERSLAB).

attribute.name: type
attribute.doc: This is ``rectangular`` to describe the region as a hyper-rectangle in the index space of its parent group's data array

field.name: parent
field.doc: The name of the data field or NXdata group in the parent group

field.name: start
field.doc: The starting position for region in detector data array. This is recommended as it also defines the region rank. If omitted then defined as an array of zeros

field.name: count
field.doc: The number of blocks or items in hyperslab selection. If omitted then defined as an array of dimensions that take into account the parent data field's shape and the ``start`` field

field.name: stride
field.doc: An optional field to define striding used to downsample data. If omitted then defined as an array of ones

field.name: block
field.doc: An optional field to define binning used to downsample data. If omitted then defined as an array of ones

field.name: scale
field.doc: An optional field to define scaling of binned data. If omitted then defined as an array of ones

group.name: downsampled_data
group.doc: An optional group containing data sliced/downsampled from parent group’s data

group.name: region_statistics
group.doc: An optional group containing any statistics derived from the region in parent group’s data such as sum, minimum, maximum, mean, mode, median, rms, variance, etc. Where more than one statistical dataset is written (specified with ``@signal``) then add ``@auxiliary_signals`` listing the others
